snippet: As a new Iraq takes shape, the centuries-old customs and swagger of tribal leaders are keeping their hold.
abstract: Ishaqi Journal; Iraq, buttressed by ideas of democracy in the wake of the American withdrawal, is still dominated by the centuries-old customs and swagger of local tribal leaders; sheiks are accustomed to dealing out swift justice, imposing harsh penalties before courts have the chance to intercede; many took up the reins of local power as a response to political crisis in Baghdad and the threat of a return to sectarian warfare.

byline.contributor: Yasir Ghazi and an employee of The New York Times contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: As a new Iraq takes shape, the centuries-old customs and swagger of tribal leaders are keeping their hold.

headline.seo: Iraq’s Tribal Chiefs Step Into the Breach With Swift Justice
headline.main: Iraq’s Tribal Chiefs Step Into the Breach With Swift Justice
headline.print_headline: Iraq’s Tribal Chiefs Step Into the Breach With Swift Justice
